Some progress on the #FranklConjecture!

Justin Gilmer used some information theoretic arguments to establish the first constant lower bound for the fraction of sets in a #UnionClosed family that contain the same element. Initially 1%, now 38% but it looks like some new ideas are required to get to the 50% of the conjecture.

Quanta article: https://www.quantamagazine.org/long-out-of-math-an-ai-programmer-cracks-a-pure-math-problem-20230103/

Gilmer’s paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09055

title: Operational Quantum Mereology and Minimal Scrambling

In classical mechanics, you combine subsystems to make the whole system. Quantum mechanics is the other way around: the whole comes first, and you decide how to divide it up. New paper on quantum mereology by Zanardi and Lloyd.

Approaching Peak Ground Truth
Florian Kofler et al. (+17)

tl;dr: if annotations are unreliable, maximizing similarity w/ those annotations leads to models != represent real world predictions. Presents Peak Ground Truth, " PGT marks the point beyond which an increase in similarity with the reference annotation stops translating to better Real World Model Performance."

Would like to know how deep learners feel about this one.

The Messier 106 Galaxy

This galaxy harbors a peculiar system in its nuclear region: a water vapor megamaser, the equivalent of a laser operating in microwave instead of visible light and on a galactic scale!

This maser plays an important role in the calibration of the cosmic distance ladder. Six such galactic maser systems are exploited in our recently published Cosmicflows-4 catalog of galaxy distances: https://arxiv.org/abs/2209.11238

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_106

Euler-Lagrange equations of motions of bosonized theory used to compute the density profile of the Majorana edge mode. title: Why high-profile journals have more retractions - Nature

last_post.content: (Singling out CNS as these are the "high prestige" journals, even if it has been shown before that they actually have a higher retraction rate https://www.nature.com/articles/nature.2014.15951)

This post on not sending people to mars https://idlewords.com/2023/1/why_not_mars.htm reminded me that there's this trail of CNS papers that the community decided are BS, but still linger without any notice or retraction. Like this one on a 250 million year old, viable bacterium https://www.nature.com/articles/35038060 or DNA from dinosaur bones https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7973705 . There's a refuting technical comment on the latter (https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.7761839), but it's not mentioned or linked from the original paper

title: Explanations as Programs in Probabilistic Logic Programming

Probabilistic logic programs are considered interpretable and thus there's no need for additional explanations. title: uiCA: Accurate Throughput Prediction of Basic Blocks on Recent Intel Microarchitectures

last_post.content:
A mic drop moment in the uiCA paper is when they show that the trivial baseline model

rthroughput = max(instructions / 4, loads / 2, stores)

beats llvm-mca and OSACA by a wide margin and approaches IACA in prediction accuracy, at least on BHive. Of course, this isn't uiCA's actual model (it has a proper pipeline model) but it puts the accuracy of those other tools into perspective. Conversely, it shows how good the baseline model is for napkin estimates.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2107.14210

This is a passion project that I've been wanting to do for a long time...

Neural Story Planning
https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.08718

Historically, partial-order planning was used to generate causally coherent stories/plots. But suffered from knowledge engineering bottlenecks.

Neural story generators struggle with coherence, repetition, and other LM artifacts.

This works updates classical planning algorithms to use an LM to infer actions and causal preconditions

Using data on natural disasters, government spending, and election returns, we show that voters reward the incumbent presidential party for delivering disaster relief spending, but not for investing in disaster preparedness spending.."

I’m writing about how agents find clients, so of course, I’m writing a bit about MFA programs. As a base, I used data from the Iowa Writer’s Workshop, compiled by Loren Glass, Nicholas Kelly & Nikki White, published at the Post45 Data Collective (https://doi.org/10.18737/CNJV1733p4520210415) and augmented by my RA. Glass, Kelly & White worked on the data for years; P45 DC took months to peer review it; my RA spent ~30 hours adding to it. All of that work enabled me to write…wait for it…3 sentences.
Cheers, 22!

In the meantime the paper ‘Predatory publishing in Scopus: evidence on cross-country differences’ has been republished in @QSS_ISSI, with some minor changes https://doi.org/10.1162/qss_a_00213.

See also my editorial co-authored with @lariviev https://doi.org/10.1162/qss_e_00214.

Dec 31 - the Age of the Universe (‘02)

https://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0205387

Measurements of the CMB+low-z, particularly the acoustic peaks from Boomerang+SN1a, determine the age of the universe: 13.7 +/- 0.2 Billion years. This result was confirmed, with similar accuracy by WMAP in ‘03.

title: What do Vision Transformers Learn? A Visual Exploration

last_post.content:
"What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration."

Vision transformers (ViTs) have fewer inductive biases the convolutional networks, so, what do ViTs actually learn? It turns out that they learn inductive biases (or features) similar to convolutional networks!

Early layers capture edges and textures, and later layers learn more complex representations to capture broader concepts.

Paper: "What do vision transformers learn? A visual exploration." (https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.06727)

People avoid discussing political issues because they overestimate the discomfort these conversations will bring. Leading them to have these conversations anyway reduces expected discomfort and increases willingness to have tough discussions in the future https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/19485506221143593

In-context learning in #transformers is one of those mysterious #ML phenomena that needs more attention (no pun intended) from #neuroscientists.

In-context learning is a phenomenon in large language models where the model "learns" a task just by observing some input-output examples, without updating any parameters.
"Simply by adjusting a “prompt”, transformers can be adapted to do many useful things without re-training, such as translation, question-answering, arithmetic, and many other tasks. Using “prompt engineering” to leverage in-context learning became a popular topic of study and discussion." (https://transformer-circuits.pub/2022/in-context-learning-and-induction-heads/index.html)

Interestingly, two recent works (H/T @roydanroy) showed that in-context learning (at least under certain conditions) match solutions found by gradient descent:
1) Transformers learn in-context by gradient descent: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.07677
2) What learning algorithm is in-context learning? Investigations with linear models: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15661

In #neuroscience, synaptic plasticity is generally thought to be the mechanism underlying many of the behavioral improvements that are loosely referred to as learning.

Could in-context #learning be an alternative mechanism underlying at least some behavioral improvements? Given the suggested similarities of the #hippocampus representation learning and transformers (https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.04035), it'd be interesting to see the implications of in-context learning for our understanding of #memory formation in the hippocampus? #NeuroAI

title: Climate change increases cross-species viral transmission risk - Nature

last_post.content:
CLIMATE CHANGE...
was on many minds. Both @EckerleIsabella and Tulio de Oliveira pointed to the same study in Nature Climate Change as one of the most important papers of the year. The authors went through 100s of reports and concluded that #climatechange was making more than half of the infectious diseases they examined worse. "Climate change is bringing animal species into contact that would not normally meet, leading to more cross-species transmissions", says Eckerle. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-022-04788-w

Authors probe local spin order of a Hubbard model with controllable frustration and doping using ultracold fermions in anisotropic optical lattices continuously tunable from square to triangular geometry. Frustration reduces range of magnetic correlations at single-site level & drives transition from collinear Néel AFM to short-range correlated 120 spiral phase. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2212_13983

title: LAMBADA: Backward Chaining for Automated Reasoning in Natural Language

last_post.content:
We know from the long history of “classical” AI techniques tha ends-means reasoning (backward chaining) can be highly effective and more efficient than forward-reasoning.

This paper achieves significant gains on logic reasoning by inducing an LM to chain backwards from conclusion to premise: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13894

The LM is “wrapped” by a larger, ire traditional algorithm. This is notable because it acknowledges that LMs can be made mire powerful with external routines.

1/3

title: “Maybe in a few years I'll be able to look at it”: a preliminary study of documentary issues in the Ukrainian refugee experience - Archival Science

last_post.content: 🔖 “Maybe in a few years I'll be able to look at it”: a preliminary study of documentary issues in the Ukrainian refugee experience | SpringerLink https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10502-022-09407-1 - This article sets out the findings of a pilot study into the documentary experiences of Ukrainian refugees in Poland. Interviews conducted by and with Ukrainian refugees consider the removal of records, the documentation of the refugee experience, the documentary requirements of border cro

Our first attempt at backward-chaining with language models wrapped an LM in a recursive question-answering routine, where the algorithm attempted to guess what questions readers might have and preemptively answer them https://arxiv.org/abs/2112.03808

Anyway, I’m pretty excited about using LMs as part of a larger, structured process instead of just entering a prompt and generating continuations.

3/3

they're less sensitive to bad features
they're not invariant to data rotations
they can easily learn irregular functions

title: Time pressure reduces misinformation discrimination ability but does not alter response bias - Scientific Reports

last_post.content:
Nice to see a new conceptual replication/extension by Sultan et al of our 2020 finding that reducing deliberation makes people more likely to believe false claims (but has no effect on belief in true claims). This is particularly important in the context of social media, where people tend to scroll quickly and not think carefully about the claims they are encountering.

New paper by Sultan et al: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-022-26209-8

Our paper (Bago et al 2020 JEPG): https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2020-00479-001
Ungated pdf: https://psyarxiv.com/29b4j
Summary Tweet thread: https://twitter.com/BenceBago/status/1220099034465144838?s=20

Also relevant is this 2020 paper of ours showing that inceasing reliance on emotion when reading news has the same effect of increasing belief in false news: https://link.springer.com/article/10.1186/s41235-020-00252-3

Compiling my yearly top-papers list and "MaxViT: Multi-axis Vision Transformer" should probably make the cut.

MaxViT is a vision transformer with local-global interaction between visual tokens within a single block.

The so-called multi-axis attention scales linearly (vs quadratic complexity in the original ViT).

You can use it for
- classification
- object detection
- instance segmentation

and generative modeling.

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2204.01697

Code: https://github.com/google-research/maxvit

title: Feasible climate mitigation - Nature Climate Change

last_post.content:
The transformative changes needed to tackle the climate crisis are happening far too slowly. We argue in Nature Climate Change that a more serious scientific and practical treatment of #feasibility is long overdue.

Feasibility analyses are key to identifying which mitigation initiatives can most effectively change the actions of target actors now and to understanding how to increase the feasibility of transformative initiatives over time.

Free link: rdcu.be/c16zK

https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-022-01563-7

title: Predicting Topological Quantum Phase Transition via Multipartite Entanglement from Dynamics

last_post.content: Today's #arXivsummary: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.13252 by Lakkaraju et. al. Authors show that the non-linearly perturbed Toric code undergoes a quantum phase from a topological phase to a a paramagnetic phase via tuning the nonlinear perturbation parameter. Loschmidt echo & time-averaged multipartite entanglement may determine whether initial state belongs to topological phase or not. #CondMat #StrEl #arXiv_2212_13251

Then I turned to the three-fold way and ten-fold way. The 'three-fold way' is Dyson's term for a classification of irreducible group representations in terms of the real numbers, complex numbers and quaternions. I explained it here:

https://arxiv.org/abs/1101.5690

The 'ten-fold way' is a fancier version, popular in condensed matter physics, that involves the 10 'super division algebras'. I explained it here:

https://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/tenfold.html

but I want to dig deeper.

(3/n)

While ZX-calculus is key to pictorial quantum (cf Picturing Quantum Processes & coming Quantum in Pictures), equally important is graphical calculus for classical-quantum interaction. It's there that spiders first appeared, then yielding ZX-calculus.

https://arxiv.org/abs/0904.1997

Our new research shows how Chinese characters have evolved to become *more* complex over the past 3600 years. This is cool because for the last three centuries scholars have assumed the exact opposite. There are even explanatory myths accounting for character simplification going back to the Han dynasty (200 BCE-200 CE)

Also cool: the study was led by Simon Jerome Han while he was an *undergraduate* at the University of Melbourne.

The Conversation article is here: https://theconversation.com/most-assume-writing-systems-get-simpler-but-3-600-years-of-chinese-writing-show-its-getting-increasingly-complex-194732
The original research is here: https://doi.org/10.1162/opmi_a_00064
Our new #preprint - FdeSolver: A Julia Package for Solving Fractional Differential Equations http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12550

title: The imprints of primordial non-gaussianities on large-scale structure: scale dependent bias and abundance of virialized objects

last_post.content:
Dec 27 - Scale Dependent Bias (‘07)

https://arxiv.org/abs/0710.4560

Local non-Gaussianity changes the formation galaxies, resembling a violation of the equivalence principle. Through this effect, galaxy surveys like SPHEREx will improve measurements of this parameter by a factor of 10.

title: Factoring integers with sublinear resources on a superconducting quantum processor

last_post.content: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12372 sure does spend a lot of space not mentioning the expected number of circuit shots it requires. It's critical to the entire premise of the paper to have a small bound on this number, and as far as I can tell they just don't talk about it. Very bad sign.

If you subscribe to the common trope that you should avoid "causal language," I strongly recommend getting all the way to the very final two paragraphs in the discussion of this paper.

There is a big plot twist there, and it might change your mind.

But to understand the potentially counterintuitive conclusion, you really really need to understand the framing and methods.

AJE pub: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137
Near identical preprint version: https://doi.org/10.1101/2021.08.25.21262631

AJE pub: https://doi.org/10.1093/aje/kwac137

This framing is so gross. To see (human!) generated (ahem: English) text to be a "vital resource" you have to be deeply committed to the project of building AI models and in this particular way.

title: There’s no room for COVID complacency in 2023

last_post.content:
"Global collaborations, such as COVAX, were established to deliver vaccines equitably. But they faltered as wealthy nations prioritized vaccinating their own populations. ...

The result is that only one-quarter of people in low-income countries have received at least one dose of a coronavirus vaccine."

https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-022-04476-9

Listening to the advice of outgroup members can make you more accurate during decision-making:

"Outgroup advice reduced the desirability effect of predicting one’s team as winning and increased accuracy."

van Swol et al. (2023). The benefits of advice from outgroup members on decision accuracy and bias reduction.

title: A non-constructive proof of the Four Colour Theorem

last_post.content:
This new claimed proof of the 4-color theorem is short, interesting, but problematic:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.09835

The basic strategy is simple, as explained by @highergeometer:

"given a map L that isn't 4-colourable, then all but an exponentially small (in # edges) proportion of graphs are not 4-colourable, because they contain L. But the proportion of 4-colourable graphs has a lower bound proportional to # edges."

But there may be problems. Maybe you can help with a really simple one!

(1/n)

Why do overall gender/racial/etc disparities in the follow network matter? Social media attention:
- improves job prospects
- gets academics more citations (& money/promotions etc)
- shapes the careers of journalists

And despite claims that Twitter was an equalizer, it concentrated attention inequalities on average.

See Usher & Holcomb on this: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/1940161218781254?casa_token=xFnipMcj3MkAAAAA%3ApXnzxTyfzdyXDcbAdK3wMLV7IWXw6h-n6ODeBW9d8RnNpekXbKGx_CF-l7M4P3xjZsDsRK-gbKYEQA
